Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Liquid Chromatograph/Mass Spectrometer for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemical Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Programs. Professor Victor Ryzhov from Northern Illinois University and colleagues Ralph Wheeler, Elizabeth Gaillard, Melissa Lenczewski and James Horn are acquiring a liquid chromatograph, ion-trap, time-of-flight mass spectrometer (LC-IT-TOF-MS). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the detection and determination of the structures of molecules in a complex mixture. In an instrument with an ion trap, a combination of magnetic and electric fields capture the charged particles. With the TOF capabilities the sample is finely vaporized into a spray, then the ions are accelerated by an electric field to allow further characterization. The liquid chromatograph component allows separation of mixtures before the components are analyzed. This acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students in research and training using this modern analytical technique. The instrument serves students and researchers from various undergraduate colleges such as Harper, Rock Valley and Knox Colleges as well as Olivet Nazarene University.

This mass spectrometer enhances research and education at all levels. The tool benefits researchers studying engineering proteins and age-related processes that could be relevant to the eye. The instrumentation is also used for studies that may be relevant for understanding proteomics, developing delivery agents for boron neutron capture, and discovering enzyme inhibitors. The mass spectrometer also enables research for new synthetic methods for complex organic synthesis; These methods that may be relevant for drug discovery studies. Finally, the instrumentation is used to study peptide photodegradation and water pollutants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award (nominally, September 2017- August 2020) the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Northern Illinois University was able to acquire and install (April 2018) a high-resolution mass spectrometer (HR-MS), a Bruker Maxis Q-TOF. the instrument immediatelyprovided an elevated research platform for the PI, co-PI, and senior personnel groups as well as state-of-the-art educational and skills training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in the department. In addition, it greatly benefited the visiting summer undergraduate students supported under a parallel NSF-REU program.

The main objectives of the proposal were to: 1) Enhance research activities of PI/co-PIs/senior personnel; 2) Train graduate and undergraduate students in HR-MS; 3) Provide an outreach tool for community college partners; 4) Use the instrument as a recruitment tool for both undergraduate and graduate Chemistry and Biochemistry programs at NIU.

The intellectual merit of this award includes three manuscripts by the PI (two published, one submitted) and several conference presentations (some online during 2020), usage of the instrument by a co-PI to develop rapid COVID testing via MS, and, most importantly, establishing an in-house HR-MS facility for Organic chemists. The latter has already produced four publications acknowledging the award, but more will be forthcoming in the near future.

The broader impacts of this proposal included expanding opportunities and experiences for the community college and PUI partners. While only virtually in 2020, an agreement has been reached for in-person visits from Kishwaukee Community College Organic Chemistry students to get trained and obtain HR-MS data at NIU in the near future. Real sample data and MS training modules were created by the PI and supplied to a Biochemistry class at Knox College and an Instrumental Analysis class in Olivet Nazarene University. Additionally, the instrument serves as one of the most appealing pieces of equipment used to recruit undergraduate and graduate students into our department, which caters to traditionally underepresented categories in STEM fields. Both undergraduate and graduate student bodies at NIU are at or slightly above 50% female, while the undergrads feature 10% Hispanic and 15% African-American (out of 150+ total). The PI group over the reporting period graduated two female Ph.D. and two B.S. Hispanic students (all working in STEM fields now).
